lens.book_chapters: All sections: How People See (Things 1-12), How People Read (Things 13-18), How People Remember (Things 19-26), How People Think (Things 27-39), How People Focus Attention (Things 40-49), What Motivates People (Things 50-62), People Are Social Animals (Things 63-71), How People Feel (Things 72-84), People Make Mistakes (Things 85-89), How People Decide (Things 90-100)

reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address the Stays Manager as the central active-lease touchpoint. guest-works-003 ('Design the Stays Manager as a System 1 Weekly Dashboard') prescribes a weekly dashboard that minimizes cognitive load. rb-ui-0931-006 (Active Stay Weekly Check-In Card) provides the specific card component that sits inside that dashboard, adding the micro-review accumulator and weekly confirmation flow.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: the nneka-call transcript shows Brad texting Nneka directly for reschedules because no platform tool exists. The Kahneman analysis shows System 1 must approve the dashboard before System 2 engages. Reverse-benchmark evidence: HotPads has zero active-stay features; Weinschenk's Thing #60 (habits = small steps over time) and Thing #52 (dopamine seeking) provide the neurological grounding for why weekly touchpoints create habits. The combined insight: the Stays Manager is validated as foundational from both user calls (inside-out) and competitor gap analysis (outside-in), and now has both cognitive psychology (Kahneman) and behavioral neuroscience (Weinschenk) frameworks supporting it.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: This is the strongest cross-process reinforcement in the system. The Stays Manager has now been independently identified by 7+ processes: Kahneman (System 1/2), Eyal (Hook Model), Christensen (Innovator's Dilemma), Lean UX/Sonder, Cialdini (reciprocation), Norman (affordances), and now Weinschenk (attention/memory/habits). The convergence signal is overwhelming. rb-ui-0931-006 adds the specific habit-formation mechanism (Thing #60: small steps over time) and the micro-review as the variable reward (Thing #51) that previous runs identified as needed but did not specify at the interaction level.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the proposal pipeline as an anxiety-resolving visibility mechanism. guest-works-001 ('Proposal Pipeline as Anxiety-Resolving Status Stream') prescribes visible proposal status to resolve guest anxiety. rb-ui-0931-005 (Proposal Status Pipeline) provides the specific UI component with stage-by-stage progress, timestamps, and host response time expectations.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: guest calls show proposal anxiety -- Frederick says 'she has an answering me back, that's boring.' The Kahneman framework shows that uncertainty triggers System 1 threat detection. Reverse-benchmark evidence: HotPads' contact form leads to complete silence; Weinschenk's Thing #55 (progress/mastery/control) and Thing #50 (goal gradient) explain why the post-inquiry void destroys motivation at peak investment. Combined: the proposal void is validated as a pain point from both user interviews and competitor analysis, with both cognitive psychology frameworks providing independent theoretical support.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: The proposal pipeline is now validated from two user-research angles (calls from hosts and guests) and two competitor angles (HotPads' void, Booking.com's review timing). The Weinschenk addition is the goal gradient analysis (Thing #50): motivation peaks near the goal, and the contact form is the closest-to-goal moment. Destroying motivation at this peak is more costly than at any other point. This elevates the proposal pipeline from 'nice to have' to 'critical path for conversion.'

reinforcements.similarity: Both specify the visual progress representation. guest-communicates-005 ('Proposal Progress Pipeline: Show the Guest Where They Are') defines the information architecture of the pipeline. rb-ui-0931-005 provides the production-ready HTML/CSS implementation with Feather icons, purple-tinted progress fills, and responsive mobile conversion to vertical timeline.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: The design-stack element prescribes the content hierarchy (current stage highlighted, completed stages with checkmarks, future stages visible). The reverse-benchmark element implements this hierarchy with production style guide compliance and adds the behavioral reasoning: Thing #55 (the three motivation drivers must be present simultaneously) and Thing #36 (time feels shorter with progress feedback). Together, they provide both the 'what' and the 'why' at production quality.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Moderate incremental boost. The primary value of this reinforcement is that the reverse-benchmark run independently arrived at the same pipeline design from competitor gap analysis, confirming it is not just a user-reported need but also a category-wide absence.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address trust formation through human identity. works-004 ('Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming') prescribes transferring trust from the agent to the platform through visual continuity (agent name, photo on dashboard). rb-ui-0931-001 (Host Identity Card) extends this to the listing level: the HOST's face and identity become the trust signal on the listing page, not just the agent's identity on the dashboard.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Andreas's trust was built with Bryant (a person), not Split Lease (a platform). The agent's name and photo on the dashboard bridges this gap. Reverse-benchmark evidence: HotPads' listing pages have zero faces, bypassing the FFA; 7 transcript quotes show users seeking identity verification (LinkedIn, Zoom, background checks). Combined: trust must be built at TWO levels -- agent trust (works-004) and host trust (rb-ui-0931-001). The design-stack element handles the agent-to-platform bridge; the reverse-benchmark element handles the host-to-guest bridge. Together, they create a complete trust architecture.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: High. The design-stack runs established that trust lives in people (agents), not platforms. The reverse-benchmark run reveals that trust must ALSO live in hosts, not just agents. This is a new dimension: as Split Lease scales and the agent layer thins, host identity becomes the primary trust signal. rb-ui-0931-001 is the element that enables this transition.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address trust credential presentation. communicates-003 ('Trust Credential Stack: Process Before Promise') prescribes showing verification mechanisms before trust claims. rb-ui-0931-001 (Host Identity Card) includes verification badges ('Verified Host', response time, guest rating) that implement this principle at the listing-card level: the verification mechanism (credit check, ID verification) is shown as a badge before the implicit trust claim (this is a safe person to live with).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Andreas's trust threshold is process-based ('excellent credit on every single tenant'). The trust credential stack must lead with mechanism, not promise. Reverse-benchmark evidence: HotPads has zero trust credentials on listings. Weinschenk's Thing #79 (look and feel = first trust indicator) means the VISUAL presence of trust badges creates trust before the content is read. The combined insight: trust badges on the Host Identity Card are not just informational -- they are visual trust signals that the FFA-adjacent processing centers evaluate in the first 170ms of viewing the card.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Moderate. This reinforcement confirms that the trust credential architecture should be applied not just at phase transitions (communicates-003's focus) but also at the listing level. The Weinschenk framework adds the neuroscience: trust badges work because of visual processing speed (Thing #79), not just because of information content.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the date management interaction pattern. guest-behaves-004 ('Date Change Request as a Three-Tap Contextual Flow') prescribes date changes within the Stays Manager at conversational speed. rb-ui-0931-006 (Active Stay Weekly Check-In Card) provides the weekly confirmation mechanism that makes date management a habitual, low-friction interaction rather than an exceptional, high-friction one.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Brad texts Nneka directly to reschedule because the platform has no fast path. The Kahneman framework shows System 2 effort must be minimized. Reverse-benchmark evidence: HotPads has no date management at all. Weinschenk's Thing #57 (people are inherently lazy) and Thing #58 (shortcuts only if easy) explain why the three-tap flow must be EASIER than texting. Combined: the date change flow and the weekly check-in card are complementary -- the check-in card is the entry point, the three-tap flow is the action. Together, they form the complete active-stay interaction loop.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Strong. The reverse-benchmark lens adds the critical insight that the weekly check-in INCLUDES date confirmation, which means the date change flow is not a separate feature but a natural extension of the weekly habit. This reframes date management from 'a tool the guest uses when plans change' to 'part of the weekly rhythm the guest already performs.'

extensions.gap_filled: Listing evaluation phase: narrative description format. No existing library element addresses how listing descriptions should be structured for cognitive processing. The library has extensive trust and identity elements but nothing about the description content format itself.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate-high confidence. The behavioral science case is strong (Thing #33 stories > data, Thing #74 anecdotes > data), and 3 transcript quotes support the need for narrative over specifications. However, the execution depends on host willingness to write narrative descriptions, which no transcript directly addresses. The host may need templates or agent-assisted drafting.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes. A design-stack run focused on the listing creation phase should specifically ask hosts: 'How would you describe what it's like to live in your space?' vs. 'What are the features of your space?' The difference in response format would validate whether hosts naturally produce narratives or need structured prompting.

extensions.gap_filled: Search phase: cross-session memory and search journey awareness. The library has no element addressing stateful search across sessions. The search phase is the thinnest coverage area in the entire library because design-stack runs analyze calls (post-search) and previous reverse-benchmark runs focused on other phases.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence. The behavioral science case is strong (Thing #22 recognition > recall, Thing #20 4-item working memory). However, Split Lease's current small listing inventory means the search memory bar may be over-engineered for the present scale. The element becomes increasingly valuable as inventory grows.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes, but indirectly. A design-stack run focused on the guest search experience should track how many sessions a guest takes to commit, and whether they revisit previously-viewed listings. This behavioral data would validate the session memory need.

extensions.gap_filled: Search phase: structured comparison tooling. No existing library element provides comparison scaffolding limited to working memory capacity. The 4-item limit from Weinschenk's Thing #20 provides the design constraint that no previous run identified.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence. The working memory limit is well-established neuroscience, and Tom C's transcript quote confirms cognitive overload. However, the comparison tray UX pattern is common in e-commerce but rare in rentals -- it may feel unfamiliar to rental searchers who have been trained by the category to browse without tools.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes. A design-stack run should observe whether guests naturally create informal comparison mechanisms (spreadsheets, screenshots, notes). If they do, the comparison tray formalizes an existing behavior. If they do not, it may introduce unwanted cognitive overhead.

extensions.gap_filled: Listing evaluation phase: temporal review narrative. Previous library elements (from the Booking.com/Hooked run) identified the need for micro-reviews during the active stay, but no element specifies how these reviews are surfaced to FUTURE guests as a trust signal. rb-ui-0931-007 closes this loop: weekly micro-reviews from rb-ui-0931-006 feed into the social proof badge on listing pages.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence for the concept, moderate for the specific timeline format. The behavioral case is strong: Thing #74 (anecdotes > data) and Thing #98 (uncertain people follow others) make social proof essential. The temporal narrative format (showing how satisfaction evolved over weeks) is novel and may need user testing to determine if it is more persuasive than a simple aggregate rating.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes. A design-stack run focused on how guests evaluate listings should test: do guests find temporal review narratives more trustworthy than aggregate star ratings? The hypothesis is that seeing satisfaction INCREASE over time is more persuasive than a static 4.9 rating.

cross_process_insights.insight: The Stays Manager is the single most converged element in the entire design stack. It has now been independently identified as foundational by 7+ processes spanning two pipeline types (design-stack and reverse-benchmark) and 7+ distinct book frameworks (Kahneman, Weinschenk, Eyal, Christensen, Cialdini, Norman, Lean UX). No other element approaches this level of cross-process validation. The reverse-benchmark run adds the neurological basis for habit formation (Thing #60: habits require small, repeated steps over time) that previous runs intuited but did not ground in neuroscience.
cross_process_insights.implication: The Stays Manager should be treated as the highest-priority engineering investment. Every week of delay is a week of missed habit formation for active guests. The weekly check-in card (rb-ui-0931-006) is the atomic unit of this habit -- it must be the first active-stay feature shipped.

cross_process_insights.insight: The trust architecture requires TWO layers that the library had not previously distinguished: agent trust (the agent-to-platform bridge, covered by works-004) and host trust (the host-to-guest bridge, covered by rb-ui-0931-001). As Split Lease scales and reduces agent dependency, host trust becomes the primary trust mechanism. The reverse-benchmark analysis reveals that the FFA (Thing #4) is the fastest trust-assessment pathway, and it is activated by faces -- which means the Host Identity Card is not a 'nice profile feature' but the foundational trust infrastructure for a platform that will eventually operate without human agents mediating every transaction.
cross_process_insights.implication: The product roadmap should explicitly plan for the transition from agent-mediated trust to host-identity-mediated trust. The Host Identity Card is the bridge element. It should be designed not just for current needs but as the trust architecture for a scaled platform where agents handle exceptions, not routine matching.

cross_process_insights.insight: The review system forms a closed loop across three elements from two processes: the weekly check-in micro-review (rb-ui-0931-006, reverse-benchmark), the batched review prompts principle (guest-communicates-003 and guest-looks-003, design-stack from Booking.com/Hooked run), and the social proof badge (rb-ui-0931-007, reverse-benchmark). These three elements create a complete cycle: capture micro-reviews during active stay, accumulate them into temporal narratives, surface them as social proof on listing pages for future guests. No single run produced this complete loop -- it emerged from the intersection of the two pipeline types.
cross_process_insights.implication: The review system should be designed as a unified pipeline, not as three separate features. The data model must flow: weekly micro-review -> accumulated review narrative -> listing social proof badge. This means the micro-review schema (from rb-ui-0931-006) must be designed from the start to produce the temporal narrative format that rb-ui-0931-007 displays.

cross_process_insights.insight: The search phase is the library's thinnest coverage area, and this is structurally predictable. Design-stack runs analyze call transcripts, which capture user experiences AFTER search (during evaluation, proposal, and active lease). Reverse-benchmark runs analyze competitor interfaces, which are richest in the search phase. This means: design-stack coverage will always be weakest in search, and reverse-benchmark coverage will always be strongest there. The two processes are structurally complementary for search-phase coverage.
cross_process_insights.implication: Future reverse-benchmark runs should prioritize search-phase analysis, since this is where the process has a structural advantage. Future design-stack runs should prioritize active-lease and post-stay analysis, where transcript evidence is richest. The processes should be deliberately sequenced to fill each other's blind spots.

cross_process_insights.insight: The pricing mental model mismatch (nightly vs. monthly) is the most pervasive design problem in the platform, now confirmed by 3 independent lenses: host-side Kahneman analysis (communicates-002: Single-Sum Financial Display), guest-side Kahneman analysis (guest-communicates-002), and competitor gap analysis (HotPads shows monthly rent clearly, which Split Lease's nightly pricing violates). The Weinschenk framework adds Thing #31 (mental models): users arrive with a monthly-rent mental model, and nightly pricing VIOLATES this model. Discovery-002 from L2 specifically identifies this: 'nightly pricing violates monthly-rent mental model.' This is no longer a hypothesis -- it is the single most validated design problem across all processes.
cross_process_insights.implication: The pricing display should show monthly equivalents as the PRIMARY number on all interfaces, with nightly rates as secondary annotation. This is not a preference -- it is a cognitive necessity validated from three independent analytical angles and two distinct behavioral science frameworks.

new_tokens_flagged: None. All 7 new elements use exclusively production style guide tokens: --primary-purple (#31135D), --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)), --accent-purple (rgb(140, 104, 238)), --success-green (#4B47CE as success purple), --chat-purple (rgb(75, 71, 206)), and all spacing, radius, shadow, and typography tokens from the style guide.
token_compliance.recommendation: No new tokens needed. Note: tokens.json uses a green accent palette (#2d5a3d) and different fonts (Instrument Serif, Outfit, IBM Plex Mono) that are NOT reflected in the production style guide. The new elements correctly use the production style guide (Inter, DM Sans, purple palette) rather than tokens.json. The token drift between tokens.json and the production style guide remains an unresolved issue flagged in previous coherence audits.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a design-stack analysis focused on the listing creation phase, using a book framework about storytelling or narrative design (e.g., Storybrand by Donald Miller, or Made to Stick by Chip & Dan Heath). The goal: determine whether hosts can produce narrative listing descriptions, or whether they need structured templates and agent assistance.
next_run_recommendations.reason: rb-ui-0931-002 (Narrative Listing Description) is the strongest new extension element, but its feasibility depends on host behavior during listing creation. No existing transcript deeply explores how hosts describe their spaces beyond the initial call. A focused listing-creation run would validate whether the narrative format is achievable at scale.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a reverse-benchmark against Airbnb's review system, using a behavioral economics framework about trust formation (e.g., Trust by Rachel Botsman, or The Speed of Trust by Stephen Covey). Focus specifically on how Airbnb's review system creates social proof for short-term stays and how Split Lease's micro-review accumulator must differ for medium-term stays.
next_run_recommendations.reason: rb-ui-0931-007 (Social Proof Badge) and rb-ui-0931-006 (Weekly Check-In) together form a complete review pipeline, but the temporal narrative format is novel and unvalidated. Comparing against Airbnb's well-established review UX would reveal what to adopt, what to reject, and what to invent for the medium-term rental context.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a design-stack analysis focused on the search/discovery phase using the guest call transcripts, applying a framework about choice architecture (e.g., Nudge by Thaler & Sunstein, or Thinking in Bets by Annie Duke). The goal: understand how guests currently navigate the search process and whether the comparison tray and session memory concepts match their actual behavior.
next_run_recommendations.reason: The search phase is the library's thinnest coverage area. rb-ui-0931-003 (Session Memory Bar) and rb-ui-0931-004 (Comparison Tray) are theoretically grounded but lack direct user behavior validation. A search-focused design-stack run would provide the inside-out evidence to complement this run's outside-in analysis.
